text: so when I decided to create an artpiece
in manat NASA the neighborhood of the
chairo garbage collector in Egypt I
never thought this project would be the
most amazing human experience that would
ever live as an North had this humanist
intention of beautifying a poor and
neglected neighborhood by bringing art
to it and hopefully Shining Light on
this isolated
Community the first time I heard about
this Christian Coptic Community was in
2009 when the Egyptian authorities under
the regime of H Mubarak decided to
slaughter 300,000 pigs using the pretext
of H1 N1 virus originally there are pig
breeders their pigs and other animal are
fed with the organic waste that they
collect on a daily basis this event kill
the life Hood the first time man n it
felt like a maze I was looking for the
Sim Monastery on top of the M Mountain
so you go right then straight then right
again then left to reach all the way to
the top but to reach there you must
Dodge between those truck overpacked
with garbage and slum between the stuk
the fastest vehicle to move around in
the neighborhood the smell of the
garbage and loaded from the cir was
intense and the noise of the traffic was
loud and overbearing add to to it the
dean created by those Crusher in those
warehouses along the way from outside
they look chaotic but everything is
perfectly
organized the zarib that's how they call
them themselves which mean the pig
breeders have been collecting the
garbage of Koo and sorting it in their
own neighborhood for decades they have
developed one of the most efficient and
highly profitable system on a global
level still the place is perceived as
dirty marginalized and segregated
because of the association with the
trash so my initial idea was to create
an anamorphic piece a piece that you
only see from one advantage point I
wanted to challenge myself artistically
by painting over several building and
having it only fully visible from one
point on the makata mountain the mkata
mountain is the pride of the community
this is where they build the Simo
Monastery a 10,000 seat cave church that
they cave into the mountain itself so
the first time I stand on top of the
mountain and I look at the neighborhood
I ask myself how on Earth will I
convince all those owner to let me paint
on their building and then mag came mag
is a guide from the church he told me
the only person that I needed to
convince was father saman who is the
leader of the community but to convince
father saman I needed to convince Mario
who is a Polish artist who moved to Koo
20 years ago and who created all the
artwork of the cave Church
I'm really grateful to Mario it was the
key of the project he managed to get me
a meeting with father saman and
surprisingly he loved the ID he asked me
about where did I paint it before and
how will make it happen and he was
mainly concerned by what I was going to
write in every work that I create I
write messages with my style of Arabic
calligraphy I make sure that those
messages are relevant to the place where
I'm painting but has this universal
dimension so anybody around the world
can relate to it so for man nasar I
decided to write in Arabic the word of
St athanasius of Alexandria a Coptic
Bishop from the 3rd Century who
said which means in English anyone who
wants to see the sunlight clearly need
to wipe his eyes first it was really
important for me that the community felt
connected to the world and for me this
quote was perfectly reflecting the
spirit of the project so father saman
blessed the project and his approval
brought all the Resident on board
hundreds of lit of paint a dozen of blue
manual lift several trip back and forth
to Koo a strong and solid team from
France North Africa Middle East and the
US and after a year of planning and
logistic there we are my team and some
member from the local community creating
a piece that will spread over 50
building some filling up the space of
the calligraphy that I trace with color
here's some blue there's some yellow
there's some orange some other like
carrying some sandbags and putting them
on the top of the building to hold those
manual lift and some other assembling
and disassembling the same lift and
moving them around the different
building at the beginning of the project
there was I numbered all those building
on my sketch and there was no real
interaction with the community people
didn't get the point of all of this but
fast enough those building number became
family name the first building was the
house of Uncle Ibrahim uncle ibraim was
such an enthusiastic person he was
always singing and making joke and um
his daughters and son saved me actually
from his bull who wanted to attack me on
the fourth
floor actually the bull saw me from the
window and came out on the
balcony
yeah uncle ibim was always hanging out
on the balcony and talking to me while I
was painting I remember him saying that
he didn't go to the mountain for 10
years years and that he never take a day
off he said that if he stop working who
will stop the who will stop the garbage
but surprisingly at the at the end of
the project he came all the way to the
mountain to look at the piece he was
really proud to see his house painted
and he said that this project was the
project of peace
and sorry
he said
that he said that was that was a project
of peace and unity that it brought
people together so his perception toward
the project change and my perception
toward the community change also and
toward what they do you know all the
garbage that everybody is disgusted by
is actually is not theirs they just work
out of it actually they don't live in
the garbage they live from the garbage
so I start doubting myself and wondering
was what was the real purpose you know
of of this whole project it was not
about beautifying a place by bringing
art to it it was about switching
perception you know and open a dialogue
on the connection that we have with
communities that we don't know so day
after day the calligraphy Circle was
taking shape and we were always excited
to go back on the mountain to look at
the piece and standing exactly at this
point every day make me realize the
symbolic behind this anamorphic piece if
you want to see the real image of
somebody maybe you should change you
know your
angle there was doubts and difficulties
like fears and stress it wasn't simple
like to work in such environment
sometime having pigs under you while you
paint or climbing a stack of garbage to
reach a lift but we all got over the
fear of the high The Swinging lift the
strength of the smell and also the
stress of not finishing on time but the
kindness of all those people made us
forget everything the building number
three was the house of Uncle bahit and
farida in Egyptian they have this
expression that
says which means the best people they
were the best people we used to take our
break in front of their houses and all
the kids of the neighborhood would to
like used to join us I was impressed and
amazed actually by the kids of manat
nasar they for the first few days they
were always refusing anything that we
were offering them if a snack or a drink
so I asked aunti farida why is that and
she she told me they teach their kids to
refuse anything from somebody that they
don't know because maybe this person
needs it more than they
do so at this exact point I realized
that actually the Zab Community was the
ideal context to raise the topic of
perception we need to question our level
of misconception and judgment we can
have you know as a society upon
communities based on their
difference I remember remember how we
got delayed on Uncle ibrahim's house
when his pigs that are breed on the
rooftop were eating the sandbags that
hold the
lift yeah the house of Uncle bit and
Auntie farida was this kind of meeting
point everybody used to gather there I
think this is what Uncle Brahim meant
when he said that was the project of
peace and unity because I really felt
that people were coming together
everyone was greeting us with a smile
offering us a drink or inviting us in
their own house for lunch you know and
sometime you're on the first level of a
building somebody open his window and
offer you some tea and then the same
thing happen on the second floor and it
keep going all the way to the top you
know
so I I think I never drink as much tea
as I did in
Egypt and to be honest with you we could
have finished earlier but I think it
took us three weeks because of all those
tea
breaks
[Applause]
yeah in Egypt they have another
expression which is naruna which means
you brought light to us in man they were
always telling us this the calligraphy
actually is a is I use a white
glow-in-the-dark paint for the
calligraphy so at the end of the project
we rented some black light projectors
and lit up the whole neighborhood
surprising everybody around we wanted to
tell them that they are the one who
brought light to us
the Zab Community are strong honest hard
worker and they know their value the
people of kro called them the zalin
which means the people of the garbage
but ironically the people of man nasar
called the people of KIRO the zalin they
say they are the one who produce the
garbage not them you
know the goal was to leave something to
this community but I feel that they are
the one who left something in our lives
you know the art project was just a
pretext for this amazing Human
Experience the art piece at some point
will disappear or vanish and actually
there's somebody who's building a second
floor in front of Uncle ibrahim's house
so it's cover part of the of the
painting so I might need to go back and
paint over
it it was about the experience about the
story about the
moment from the street of the
neighborhood the painting is in fragment
isolated from one another standing alone
but connected with the sign of
calligraphy that today reveal the
profound message that we should all
think about before we want to judge
somebody anyone who wants to see the
sunlight clearly need to wipe his eyes
first thank you
